questions.question: What technological change did Jesse Pollak warn about potentially causing mild degradation on Farcaster web and mobile clients on February 5, 2026?
options: Significant changes at the database layer on Farcaster's backend.
A rollout of new authentication protocols.
Migration of hubs to the Base L2 chain.
Deployment of a new Neynar API version.
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak warned on 2026-02-05 that significant changes at the database layer were being made, which might cause mild degradation.

questions.question: What analogy did Jesse Pollak use to describe the potential future combination of LLMs, attached knowledge bases, and folding displays?
questions.explanation: On 2026-01-30, Jesse Pollak stated that Tom Riddle's diary will no longer be fiction, describing the combination of LLMs/agents and folding displays.

questions.question: According to the post from Base_official, what happened to their revenue in one week, causing surprise?
options: It hit a new all-time low.
questions.explanation: The Base official account posted on 2024-03-15 that they doubled their revenue and had no idea why.

questions.question: What was the main benefit of putting Neynar Studio on the web, according to Jesse Pollak?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak stated the move to web was 'for some more real estate' (2026-01-23).

questions.question: What primary function does FarBump provide for token holders, according to Brian Armstrong’s post?
questions.explanation: FarBump is described as automating 'volume trade microbuy customize time interval customize buy amount' (2026-01-25).

questions.question: Which two individuals or groups did Jesse Pollak give massive props to for making Farcaster what it is today before he and Neynar started building the protocol itself?
options: @dwr, @v, and the amazing team at Merkle.
The Coinbase engineering team and Base Core.
Vitalik Buterin and the Ethereum Foundation.
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak specifically thanked '@dwr, @v, and the amazing team at Merkle' on 2026-01-21.

questions.question: What AI model did Brian Armstrong mention is being offered for free unlimited use to 'vibecoders' by NVIDIA?
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong mentioned the 'free unlimited kimi 2.5 model provided by nvidia' on 2026-02-03.

questions.question: What simple tool did Brian Armstrong use to receive and reply to bug reports quickly after a UI refactoring?
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong mentioned receiving and replying to bug reports through @beeper within a minute on 2026-01-28.

questions.question: Who did Jesse Pollak credit for curating the `@neynar/ui`?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak noted that `@neynar/ui` was 'curated by the humans at neynar (all @obringer.eth really)' on 2026-01-05.

questions.question: What product update did Jesse Pollak specifically mention releasing 'Just in time... over the holidays' in December 2025?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak posted about 'App Studio updates for you to build something over the holidays' on 2025-12-24.

questions.question: Dan Romero inquired about regular usage of which generative AI search tool in February 2026?
questions.explanation: Dan Romero asked: 'Anyone a regular user of Perplexity these days?' on 2026-02-07.

questions.question: During the planned authentication upgrades on dev.neynar.com, which components were explicitly stated as *not* being impacted?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak stated that 'API, webhooks and other products will not be impacted' (2026-01-13).

questions.question: What primary function does ROASTR offer, enabling users to earn $ROAST?
questions.explanation: ROASTR allows users to 'earn $ROAST by daily checkin and roasting others' (2026-01-25).

questions.question: What task did Brian Armstrong utilize Clawdbot for related to his calendar and email?
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong listed 'Outlook calendar / email management' as a current use case for Clawdbot (2026-01-25).

questions.question: Which of these quotes represents Jesse Pollak's perspective on feature requests?
options: the most joyful feature requests are the ones we've already shipped
the most complex feature requests take the longest to ship
all feature requests must be on-chain
we only prioritize requests from verified users
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak posted on 2026-01-05: 'the most joyful feature requests are the ones we've already shipped'.

questions.question: A key update to Neynar Studio on the web included securely configuring what feature?
questions.explanation: The update included the ability to 'securely configure Environment Variables & secrets' (2026-01-23).

questions.question: What part of its SDK documentation process did Neynar recently automate?
options: Automated publishing documentation for our Node.js SDK.
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak announced: 'We automated publishing documentation for our Node.js SDK' (2026-01-02).

questions.question: What internal tool used for configuring webhook filters is also planned to power the App Studio agent for natural language configuration?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak stated the 'same MCP tool powering it will also power the App Studio agent' for configuring filters using natural language (2025-12-23).

questions.question: Jesse Pollak was surprised by how many people were discovering/trying which company's AI products late in the adoption timeline?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak was surprised by late adoption/discovery of 'Claude and other Anthropic products' (2026-01-14).

questions.question: What specific humanoid robot model did Jesse Pollak mention potentially receiving OpenClaw agent access?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak asked if an OpenClaw agent had been given access to 'a humanoid like the G1' (2026-02-03).

questions.question: When Neynar transitioned from building infrastructure to building the protocol, what aspect did Jesse Pollak emphasize they would deliver the same energy into?
questions.explanation: Pollak said, 'If you've ever shipped something on Neynar APIs, you know how much we care about developer experience. We'll strive to deliver the same energy into the protocol...' (2026-01-21).

questions.question: What is 'Claude Flow', as described by Brian Armstrong?
options: An orchestrator that spins up multiple claude code agents and assigns jobs.
A Base smart contract for managing agent payments.
A latency monitoring tool for Farcaster hubs.
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong described Claude Flow as 'an orchestrator that spins up multiple claude code and assigns a job to each agent' (2026-01-25).

questions.question: What is the security tool 'Tirith' recommended by Brian Armstrong used to protect against when running curl copy-pastes?
questions.explanation: Armstrong advised using Tirith to stay protected from 'homograph attacks (using identical-looking Cyrillic characters)' (2026-02-04).

questions.question: What token is required as credit to run the FarBump bot?
questions.explanation: The post explicitly states: '*you need $BUMP token as credit to run the bot not ETH' (2026-01-25).

questions.question: What specific type of latency improvement (and percentage) did Jesse Pollak highlight for @mcilroyc's account on January 30th?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak celebrated '50% less global p95 latency' for @mcilroyc (2026-01-30).

questions.question: Brian Armstrong suggested that if you are 'vibecoding' and not using 'Agentation.dev,' you are missing out. What does that tool likely relate to?
questions.explanation: The post mentioning 'vibecoding' and linking to 'agentation.dev' implies the tool is related to agent building or environment setup (2026-01-29).

questions.question: Mircea Pasoi (Coinbase) built an incomplete Python port of which library to learn how Farcaster Hubs work?
questions.explanation: Mircea Pasoi built an incomplete Python port of `@farcaster/hub-nodejs` (2023-04-09).

questions.question: According to Dan Romero, onchain channel creation moves the FIP-2 primitive one step closer to being what for humans and agents alike?
options: A virtual machine / social network in a box.
questions.explanation: Romero said channel creation moves FIP-2 one step closer to being 'a virtual machine / social network in a box for humans and agents alike' (2026-02-04).

questions.question: What did Dan Romero suggest was the key challenge with building a bot-based social network?
options: Unclear if ads work on bots.
The difficulty of maintaining decentralized hosting.
Preventing sybil attacks from malicious agents.
questions.explanation: Dan Romero stated: 'The challenge with a bot-based social network is unclear if ads work on bots' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: What condition did Dan Romero suggest would make it more sensible to have a personal agent than a personal website?
options: When the majority of web browsing by humans is done via agents.
When LLM inference costs drop to zero.
When wallets are fully embedded in OS.
questions.explanation: Romero asked this question based on the premise: 'When majority of web browsing by humans is done via agents' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: What service did Brian Armstrong share a link for that allows users to take their 'Claude Code session on the go'?
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong linked to 'https://happy.engineering/' for portability of Claude Code sessions (2026-02-06).

questions.question: In the context of the posts, what phrase did Brian Armstrong associate with Beeper's functionality?
questions.explanation: Brian Armstrong noted that Beeper's feature to filter bug reports meant '"filter the noise" really works' (2026-01-28).

questions.question: What key feature did Dan Romero note was surprisingly absent despite the release of 'agentic-enabled Xcode'?
options: A meaningful increase in new mobile apps.
questions.explanation: Dan Romero was 'Genuinely surprised we haven’t seen a meaningful increase in new mobile apps' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: What was the first role Coinbase (Mircea Pasoi) was hiring for after closing their fundraising round in late 2023?
questions.explanation: The post states the first role they were hiring for was a 'product designer' (2023-11-17).

questions.question: What personal preference did Dan Romero suggest for dealing with new channels in Slack?
options: Integrate them with a personal agent.
questions.explanation: Dan Romero suggested: 'Slack should allow all new channels you get added to default to Mute and hide' (2026-02-04).

questions.question: What was the suggested premise for an alternate timeline where Google had a legitimate search rival?
options: Subscription-based and focused on getting you the right answer.
Fully decentralized and runs on blockchain.
questions.explanation: Romero suggested a rival that 'wasn't free-with-ads but instead subscription-based and focused on getting you the right answer' (2026-02-04).

questions.question: Dan Romero predicted an order of magnitude increase in installed consumer crypto wallets in 2026. What corresponding metric did he express uncertainty about?
options: Corresponding increase in monthly transacting consumers.
questions.explanation: Romero stated: 'Unclear what the corresponding increase in monthly transacting consumers will be' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Dan Romero argued that what factor is responsible for agentic interfaces replacing good UI?
questions.explanation: Romero states: 'Agentic interfaces replacing good UI is a function of latency' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Brian Armstrong gave his OpenClaw agent sudo powers and one instruction for a 'weekend cook.' What was that instruction?
options: “Build a trustless place where agents can work together.”
questions.explanation: The instruction was: '“Build a trustless place where agents can work together.”' which resulted in an agent-only marketplace (2026-01-31).

questions.question: Dan Romero suggested an at-scale agent-native social network would probably look more like which two retro platforms?
questions.explanation: Romero noted it would look like 'OG Quora or Yahoo Answers' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Dan Romero noted that despite Threads posting 'monster MAU numbers,' what is something he has never seen screenshotted on X?
questions.explanation: He noted he's 'never seen an important Threads post screenshotted on X' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Jesse Pollak stated that he wanted to do what specific activity related to prediction markets, rather than making or betting on them?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak stated: 'i want to resolve them' (2025-12-17).

questions.question: Brian Armstrong's security PSA warned against homograph attacks using characters from which alphabet?
questions.explanation: The post specifies 'stay safu from homograph attacks (using identical-looking Cyrillic characters)' (2026-02-04).

questions.question: Dan Romero suggests a big consumer company could be built for 'public personal agents' that handle what type of interaction first?
options: Cold outreach, like iOS call screening.
questions.explanation: He suggested the agent would handle 'other cold outreach happens first with us agent, like iOS call screening' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Brian Armstrong's OpenClaw agent designed and shipped an agent-only marketplace on Base, requiring what mechanism for agent-to-agent hiring?
questions.explanation: The resulting marketplace employed agents hiring each other 'under on-chain escrow on Base' (2026-01-31).

questions.question: Dan Romero linked 'Vibe coding' to the concept of 'software factories.' What does he suggest the 'Claude Code / Clawdbot' breakout moment will be 10x as big for?
questions.explanation: Romero claimed the breakout moment 'for agentic deep research is going to be 10x as big' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: What part of Apple's existing ecosystem does Dan Romero suggest gives them all the pieces for a 10x consumer UX meta agent harness (Clawdbot)?
questions.explanation: Dan Romero listed iCloud, Shortcuts/Automations, Containers at OS level, and access to all important data as pieces Apple has, noting iCloud specifically as seamless access between devices (2026-02-07).

questions.question: Dan Romero contrasts 'Vibe coding' with what alternative approach to development?
questions.explanation: Dan Romero linked to a piece titled 'Vibe coding —> software factories' (2026-02-07).

questions.question: What type of technical visibility did Jesse Pollak mention helps improve the bot faster?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak posted simply: 'tool call visibility helps us improve the bot faster' (2026-01-21).

questions.question: The Base official account asked gym goers for advice on what topic in March 2023?
options: Staying consistent but still pushing yourself.
How to set up a home gym.
questions.explanation: The post asked for the best advice for 'staying consistent but still pushing yourself' (2023-03-25).

questions.question: In the context of US exchanges and market order spreads, which exchange did Jesse Pollak note had a lower spread (0.85%) than Coinbase Advanced (1%)?
questions.explanation: Jesse Pollak compared Coinbase Advanced (1%) to 'robinhood is at 0.85%' (2026-01-06).

questions.question: What common communication problem did Brian Armstrong use Beeper to solve, according to his post?
options: Filtering the noise to check and reply to bug reports quickly.
questions.explanation: He noted that Beeper's 'filter the noise' feature allowed him to check and reply to bug reports within a minute (2026-01-28).
